clinical_study.official_title: Decision-Making, Impulsivity and Suicidality: A Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation Study in Healthy Subjects

brief_summary.textblock: In this study the investigators aim to assess whether transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS; a safe and non-invasive method for modulating the activity of specific brain regions) when applied over the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) or the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) is able to enhance decision-making and decrease impulsivity in healthy participants.

detailed_description.textblock:
In this single-blind, sham-controlled study, the investigators aim to assess whether transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS; a safe and non-invasive method for modulating the activity of specific brain regions) when applied over the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) or the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) is able to enhance decision-making abilities and reduce impulsivity levels in healthy volunteers.
The investigators hypothesize that tDCS particularly over the left OFC and the right DLPFC, in comparison to sham rTMS, will significantly enhance decision-making and decrease impulsivity.
The investigators will enroll 110 healthy individuals aged 18-45 years. These individuals will be assessed with several instruments (including clinician-administered, self-reported and computer-based) Assessments will be carried out before and after a 30-minute tDCS session.
Our study could result in a better understanding of the neurobiological basis of well-known predisposing factors for suicidal behavior in subjects at high risk for suicide, namely decision-making deficits and heightened impulsivity. Undoubtedly, a novel safe and non-invasive method for decreasing the vulnerability to suicidality among high risk individuals would be a promising therapeutic intervention for suicide prevention.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Men or women aged 18 to 45 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence any psychiatric and/or neurological illness
- Psychoactive substance abuse/dependence in the past 6 months
- Current use of medication(s) that might influence cognition and/or affective status
- Presence of an uncontrolled medical disease (e.g., cardiovascular, renal)
- Pregnancy and/or lactation
- Specific contraindication for tDCS (e.g., metallic head implant).
